Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Spectral clustering with tensors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Society is awash in complex data that is recorded by high-resolution sensors and through our traces of online activity. One of the key challenges in turning this data into actionable insight is finding hidden groups in these data. For instance, finding similar types of land based on its spectral composition, or finding groups of like-minded people in a social network. While there are a variety of methods to solve these problems that are known already, there are none that take advantage of the multi-dimensional features of the data in an integrated way. The work in this proposal will provide an entirely new type of data clustering, or grouping. The method exploits the rich features of these complex modern datasets. Having access to such a method will help society improve its understanding of the results of complex scientific experiments, produce new insights into the common patterns in social networks, and extract valuable information from large databases of sensor information. The methods developed will be general, and thus, they will have broad applicability that will enrich our capability to use data to benefit society.

Spectral clustering is a technique to identify cohesive groups in a database based on simple pairwise relationships between the items. In a social network, for example, people are connected based on pair-wise friendship relationships. This two-way, or two-dimensional, association between people does not capture the richness of real-world social interactions that often involve multiple people. These higher-order interactions among groups will be represented as tensors and hyper-graphs in this project. For instance, an interaction among three people corresponds to a hyper-edge, which will be represented by a three-dimensional tensor. Thus, this project will investigate novel formulations of the spectral clustering problem that work on multi-dimensional relationships represented with tensors. These new methods and their variations will be evaluated based on the insights that they provide into (i) hyper-spectral imaging data, where each pixel has a large number of frequencies measured; (ii) in social network data, where groups of interactions create higher-order relationships; and (iii) in complex simulation data, where parametric variation creates multi-dimensional data and relationships based on space, time and parameters. This project will also investigate fast algorithms to identify the clusters based on the new formulations of spectral clustering, as well as relations between these algorithms and emerging work in computational topology.

All of the software developed as part of this project will be released as open source software in order to maximize its impact. The investigator will organize tutorials on these new formulations at major conferences to attract additional applications.

For further information see the project web site at: https://www.cs.purdue.edu/homes/dgleich/tensors

POR.DRECONTENT:
Almost everyone has seen a table of numbers. These could be weather forecasts where there are locations in the columns of the table and times are the rows of the table. The entries of the table would probably indicate the temperature forecast. When a table of data is used by a computer scientist, it is often called a matrix of data. A matrix can be used to summarize weather forecasts as discussed above, or it can also be used to indicate relationships between a set of objects. For instance, printed road atlases would often include a matrix of estimated travel times between locations in the atlas. The reason to use a matrix is that we can study many different types of data in terms of a general matrix without worrying about where the data comes from. For instance, another matrix could measure how many connections there are among various regions of the mouse brain.

An extremely important problem that people try to solve on a matrix is the clustering problem. Given a matrix of data, find groups within this data. In terms of the mouse brain, we know that most brains separate into halves and have fewer connections between each half that within the half. This is something that an algorithm looking at a matrix of data could easily find. The idea with such algorithms is that we can use them to study far more complex types of data where we are not sure about the groups.

 The key intellectual metric underlying this project is that we can look at data beyond just tables and matrices. A cube of data with rows, columns, and slices is often called a tensor or hypermatrix.  Whereas there are well established methods and well understood tradeoffs when finding groups in a matrix of data, methods that will form groups based on a tensor of data are not yet well understood. This project sought to understand one particular class of algorithms to take a cube of data and divide it into groups. As an example of what happened when we applied our new algorithm to a cube of data that represented flights between different airports on different airlines, we found six groups. One group represented a set of global airlines and global transportation hubs such as Atlanta, Beijing, JFK, London, Los Angeles, and other global  transportation hubs, as well as airlines such as American, United, Delta, British Airways, and Air China, which all have global reach. The next groups represented regional hubs and regional airlines. Such as a group of airlines that only operate in North America, another group that operates in Europe, and another group for Asia. When we compared these results against a matrix-based algorithm, that algorithm could only find the regional pieces and missed the global hubs that our new method found.

 Our algorithm works by taking the data cube and carefully constructing a matrix that represents the behavior of something called a spacey random walk. This matrix is designed to encode subtle properties of the data cube that are otherwise hidden. The spacey random walk is something that conceptually moves around places represented by data randomly, for example it moves between airports and airlines in the example above. But the spacey random walk periodically forgets pieces of information, which is called spacing out. After spacing out, the spacey walk continues randomly moving around the data based on an guess about where it was. While this may sound a bit contrived, this method spends most of its time on interesting pieces of the datacube as our analysis shows. This spacey walk methodology led to new further developments in algorithms for data cubes that are still being pursued in the research literature.

The broader impact of our work includes training a number of PhD students. The PI funded one student through the final years of a PhD with this project in addition to partially supporting others at various stages of their degrees. There is public software released associated with all of the research in the project. There is a public tutorial lecture on the new developments in data cube manipulation that was presented at a major international conference.
